text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Hello, this is Sarah Lucas.

I'm here to walk you
through the resume
section of our application.

To begin with, we think of
the resume as a roadmap.

It gives us an
at-a-glance overview

of your educational
background, work experience,

and key activities or
interests beyond work.

As we read your application,
we use the resume
as a guide to follow your path.

So keeping that
in mind, and so we

don't get lost
following your journey,

keep the format
simple, easy to read,

with clearly labeled
dates and locations.

Rarely is a resume
longer than a page or two
necessary for our application.

However, in sticking
to that guidance,

please do not
shrink down the font

to cram in every bullet
point you can come up with.

Focus on what's most
important to you in your path.

Moreover, please, please
avoid the temptation

to stand out with hard-to-read
fonts, extra images
and photos, or unusual formats.

That's what we're
looking for in a resume.

Finally, if you run out
of room in other parts
of the application--

for instance, in
talking about awards

or extracurricular
activities, or you

want to include more than
three recent employment

positions-- please feel free
to include those on your resume
as well.

For more information, visit
our application process page.
And good luck.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
